speaker: Facebook posts
vclaim: A picture shows that climate change protestors left garbage all over their protest side.
date: stated on September 20, 2019 in a Facebook post:
title: This picture doesn't show garbage left by the protestors on the climate strike.
text: It is estimated that up to 4 million people participated in a global climate strike on 20 September to call for action by the Government on climate change. But one of the widely shared images claims that these protesters do not do what they preach. The photograph, which was posted on Facebook on 20 September, alleges that it shows a field full of waste left behind by demonstrators. "Yeah, listen to the children, and they'll direct our planet, and I think they haven't learned the basics yet," The article was referred to as part of Facebook efforts to combat false news and misleading information in its news broadcast. ∙ (Read more about our partnership with Facebook.) We've shared more than 130,000 times, so we wanted to check it out. It turns out that the picture does not show the effects of any climate strike demonstrations - it was taken months before they occurred. It was published on January 25, 2021 in a video that says Bill Gates "at least 3 billion people must die" from this planet. By Daniel Funk • January 27, 2012, we found that the viral image in Facebook was at least five months old using a reverse image. It was initially posted on the Internet in April after an event celebrating 420, a holiday for marijuana fans, at Hyde Park in London. However, even in April, the picture was taken out of context and misunderstood in an attempt to distort the image of climate-change protestors. There's a lot of wrong information on Twitter this morning. This image is the result of an informal event in Hyde Park on Saturday, not the protesters of the exploration rebellion in the Arch marble. It costs us millions to remove #letter every year. Please take her home. Pic.twitter.com/F1JtAqmnVO - Royal Parks (@thyroyalparks) April 23, 2019 at the same time as 420 in Hyde Park, climate change activists who were part of a so-called extinction movement were protesting in various locations around Central London. We found the wrong picture of the garbage in several responses to tweets from activists such as Greta Thunberg, who gave a speech to the demonstrators on 21 April. The Swedish teenager is also credited with inspiring the climate strike of 20 September. The Facebook mail is inaccurate. We assess it wrong.
